Problem:
Consider a complex function defined by \( z(t) = e^{At}x \), where A is a constant matrix and x is a constant complex vector. We analyze the effect of applying a Laplace transformation given by \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\}(s) = \int_0^\infty e^{-st}z(t) \, dt \).

If the vector \( x \) is transformed by \( z(t) \) at \( t = 0 \) and \( z(t) \) is subsequently subjected to the Laplace transform \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\} \) without further intervention, will \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\}(s) \) depend only on the matrix \( A \)?
Explanation: The Laplace transform of \( z(t) \), which is fundamentally linked to the matrix \( A \), will be determined by the structure and properties of \( A \) after transformation. Specifically, \( \mathcal{L}\{z(t)\}(s) = (sI - A)^{-1}x \), indicating dependence solely on \( A \).
